Research article The microscopic mechanisms and essential factors governing regioselectivity in Rh-catalyzed hydroformylation of allyl acetate via DFT and microkinetic modeling Minhua Zhang Supervision Software Project administration Funding acquisition Conceptualization a b c Yuzhe Sun Writing – original draft Visualization Validation Formal analysis a b c Lingtao Wang Writing – review & editing Supervision Methodology a b c Hao Gong Supervision Software Investigation a b c Yifei Chen Writing – review & editing Validation Supervision a b c ⁎ a Key Laboratory for Green Chemical Technology of Ministry of Education, R&D Center for Petrochemical Technology, Tianjin University, Tianjin 300072, China Key Laboratory for Green Chemical Technology of Ministry of Education R&D Center for Petrochemical Technology Tianjin University Tianjin 300072 China Key Laboratory for Green Chemical Technology of Ministry of Education, R&D Center for Petrochemical Technology, Tianjin University, Tianjin 300072, China b Zhejiang Institute of Tianjin University, Ningbo, Zhejiang 315201, China Zhejiang Institute of Tianjin University Ningbo Zhejiang 315201 China Zhejiang Institute of Tianjin University, Ningbo, Zhejiang 315201, China c State Key Laboratory of Engines, Tianjin University, Tianjin 300072, China State Key Laboratory of Engines Tianjin University Tianjin 300072 China State Key Laboratory of Engines, Tianjin University, Tianjin 300072, China ⁎ Corresponding author at: Key Laboratory for Green Chemical Technology of Ministry of Education, R&D Center for Petrochemical Technology, Tianjin University, Tianjin 300072, China. Key Laboratory for Green Chemical Technology of Ministry of Education R&D Center for Petrochemical Technology Tianjin University Tianjin 300072 China Graphical abstract The direct hydroformylation of allyl acetate followed by hydrogenation represents a novel route for 1,4-butanediol production with significant industrial potential and market prospects. In this study, we employed Density Functional Theory (DFT) and Microkinetic Modeling (MKM) to comparatively investigate two representative Rh-based catalysts with distinct product distributions (RhH(CO)2(Xantphos) and RhH(CO)2(PPh3)2), systematically elucidate the mechanisms for improving the selectivity and regulation principles of this reaction. Theoretical calculations reveal that the regioselectivity is primarily determined by the olefin insertion step. Xantphos ligand reduces the electron density of the Rh center and provides a sterically favorable environment for the linear pathway. Additionally, the acetoxy group in allyl acetate exerts a repulsive interaction with the Rh-carbonyl, directing Rh to preferentially coordinate with the β-C, thereby significantly enhancing the formation of 4-acetoxybutyraldehyde. In contrast, the PPh3-modified Rh catalyst exhibits lower steric hindrance along the branched pathway, thus favoring the formation of branched aldehydes. Experimental investigations demonstrate that hydrogenolysis of allyl acetate predominantly occurs at the uncoordinated Rh sites, and the elevated H2 concentration and higher temperature will promote this side reaction. For Xantphos, MKM simulations indicate that the increased pressure and optimized syngas composition (CO/H2 = 0.5–2) can lead to linear aldehyde selectivity exceeding 98 %. Similarly, in the PPh3 system, high pressure and a near-equimolar syngas ratio favor the formation of branched aldehyde. These findings unveil the intrinsic relationships between ligand design, reaction conditions and selectivity, establishing a structure–activity framework for hydroformylation of acetoxy-functionalized olefins. This work provides critical theoretical guidance for the rational design of efficient catalysts and advances the development of scalable 1,4-BDO production process. Keywords Allyl acetate Hydroformylation Xantphos DFT MKM Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction 1,4-Butanediol (1,4-BDO) is an important organic chemical intermediate, which can be used to produce high-value downstream products such as spandex, battery electrolytes, polyurethane materials, and engineering plastics [1–3]. The production of 1,4-BDO from propylene is one of the main industrial processes, offering significant market and economic advantages in regions with abundant propylene resources [4–6]. This process initially produces allyl alcohol via propylene oxide isomerization or hydrolysis of allyl acetate [7,8], followed by further hydroformylation and hydrogenation to produce 1,4-BDO [9,10]. While the process is straightforward and utilizes stable and recyclable catalyst, the intermediate allyl alcohol is highly toxic and unstable, posing difficulties in storage and transportation. Therefore, the direct hydroformylation of allyl acetate instead of allyl alcohol, followed by hydrogenation to synthesize 1,4-BDO has garnered significant attention in the industry [11]. This approach not only retains the advantages of the propylene-based process but also enhances the safety of the production process, representing a new 1,4-BDO production route with great potential for industrialization and market prospects. In the development of the propylene-allyl acetate-1,4-BDO process, the hydroformylation of allyl acetate to synthesize 4-acetoxybutyraldehyde is the most challenging technology, determining the final product yield [12]. Early studies mainly used it as a probe molecule for the hydroformylation of ester-functionalized olefins [13–15]. Recently, research has focused on developing allyl acetate hydroformylation catalysts with high n/i ratios, and significant progress has been made in experiments. Anil et al. [16] reported a polyethylene glycol functionalized with diphenylphosphino groups for a polymeric Rh catalyst, achieving 94 % total aldehyde selectivity and a l/b ratio of 2.6 at 323 K, 40 bar for 4 h. Zhang et al. [17] found that 2,4-difluorophenyl tetraphosphine ligands with strong electron-withdrawing groups could selectively catalyze the production of straight-chain aldehydes from functionalized allyl derivatives, achieving a l/b ratio of 26 at 393 K, 100 bar syngas for 2 h. Liu et al. [11] reported that Xantphos-modified Rh(acac)(CO)2 catalysts could achieve 80 % yield of 4-acetoxybutyraldehyde. While some experiments have confirmed that changing phosphine ligands can alter product distributions, the underlying reasons and theoretical studies on allyl acetate hydroformylation remain unexplored. Wilkinson and colleagues proposed in 1968 that the hydroformylation reaction might follow two pathways: associative and dissociative [18]. Existing theoretical and experimental literature predominantly supports the dissociative mechanism. While extensive theoretical calculations and experimental validations exist for the hydroformylation of terminal olefins such as ethylene [19–22], propylene [20,23–25] and styrene [26,27], theoretical research on the hydroformylation of acetoxy-containing olefins remains in its early stages, with only a few studies on vinyl acetate [28,29]. Ding and co-workers [30] studied the performance of Rh-P-N-POPs heterogeneous catalysts in the hydroformylation of vinyl acetate through experiments and theoretical calculations. They attributed the high selectivity for linear aldehydes to the confinement effect of the ligand, which hinders acetate chelation, and the N atom which provides an electron-deficient coordination environment for the active Rh center. Li et al. [31] investigated the Rh-catalyzed asymmetric hydroformylation of vinyl formate modified by CHIRAPHOS-type ligands and identified the H2 oxidative addition step as the rate-determining step. Despite some similarities between allyl acetate and vinyl acetate, there are significant differences in product selectivity [14]. To clarify the factors affecting the selectivity in allyl acetate hydroformylation, comprehensive theoretical calculations of the reaction pathway are necessary. This will guide the design of targeted ligands to enhance the selectivity for 4-acetoxybutyraldehyde. Additionally, unlike α-olefins, allyl acetate may undergo hydrogenolysis at high temperatures, affecting aldehyde selectivity [32–34]. However, the active site for hydrogenolysis and its competition with hydroformylation are still unclear, requiring further investigation through theoretical calculations. Based on current research, Rh-catalyzed hydroformylation of allyl acetate with Xantphos modification can achieve a high l/b ratio of product selectivity [11,32], which has been also confirmed by our experiments. Moreover, we found that the l/b ratio for hydroformylation catalyzed by PPh3 ligand ranges from 0.5 to 0.9. Therefore, this study focuses on the detailed theoretical calculations of two typical Rh catalysts (RhH(CO)2(Xantphos) and RhH(CO)2(PPh3)2) in the hydroformylation of allyl acetate. We explain the factors influencing the aldehyde selectivity in allyl acetate hydroformylation in terms of electronic effects and steric hindrance, and explore the structure–activity relationship of ligands for the hydroformylation of acetoxy-containing olefins. Combining experiments and microkinetic simulations, we analyze the key steps in allyl acetate hydroformylation. Additionally, comparative experiments reveal that the active site for hydrogenolysis is primarily Rh site without phosphine ligand coordination, and theoretical calculations indicate that allyl acetate is the main species undergoing hydrogenolysis. The purpose of this study is to give a comprehensive understanding of hydroformylation of propenyl derivatives and acetoxy-functionalized olefins, with a particular focus on elucidating how to regulating the selectivity of allyl acetate hydroformylation. 2 Methods 2.1 Theoretical calculation 2.1.1 DFT calculation All Density Functional Theory (DFT) calculations in this study were performed using ORCA [35–38]. In the theoretical calculations for hydroformylation, the M06-2X functional [39–41] has proven to be adept at accurately capturing experimental regioselectivity. Moreover, it offers an authentic description of medium-range, nonlocal dispersion effects [42–45]. Geometry optimization and transition state search were using the M06-2X functional with a mixed basis set, where non-metal elements (C, H, O, P) were described with the 6-31G* basis set [46,47]and Rh was described with the SDD basis set. Frequency analysis was calculated at the same theoretical level to confirm that the optimized structures correspond to stable conformations, as well as to ensure that the transition state has only one imaginary frequency associated with the reaction bond formation or cleavage. Single-point energy was calculated at the M06-2X/def2-TZVP level [48] on the optimized geometry. All calculations were conducted using the SMD model [49] to simulate the liquid phase environment, considering the solvation effect of toluene. Dispersion corrections were applied using Grimme's DFT-D3 method [50,51]. When calculating Gibbs free energy, corrections for enthalpy and entropy were considered based on the partition functions obtained from frequency analysis under actual reaction condition, which were computed using Shermo [52]. Unless otherwise specified, Gibbs free energies were corrected at 20 bar and 353 K. The activation energy ( E a ) and reaction energy ( Δ E ) were calculated to quantify the energy changes during the reaction process, as defined by the following equations: (1) E a = E TS - E IS (2) ΔE = E FS - E IS where E TS , E FS , E IS represent the energies of the transition state, initial state, and final state, respectively. In this study, the visualization of molecular structures was achieved using CYLview [53]. For the visualization of electronic effects, the Interaction Region Indicator (IRI) [54] analysis method was employed. The grid data calculations were performed using Multiwfn [55,56], and the isosurface diagrams of the structures were rendered using VMD software [57] (detailed methods are provided in the Supporting Information). The SambVca [58–60] program is used to calculate, analyze and visualize the steric hindrance of organic ligands in metal coordination compounds. 2.1.2 MKM simulation Microkinetic Modeling (MKM) is a dynamic method which can simulate the temporal evolution of species involved in catalytic reactions, providing a description of the catalytic system that closely resembles experimental observations [61,62]. In the hydroformylation process, MKM simulation enables the investigation of how variations in temperature, pressure and syngas composition affect product distribution, which is highly beneficial for elucidating reaction mechanisms, optimizing reaction conditions, and improving catalyst design [63–65]. In this study, the reaction network for the allyl acetate hydroformylation was constructed based on DFT-calculated elementary reactions. The forward and reverse reaction rate constants were derived using Equation (3). Here, σ represents the reaction path degeneracy, which is considered in the form of point group symmetry when calculating thermodynamic quantities using Shermo, without the need for additional calculations. The tunneling correction factor κ is commonly assumed to 1 in homogeneous systems [61]. The Boltzmann constant ( k b = 1.381 × 10-23 J/K) and Planck constant ( h = 6.626 × 10-34 J·s) are employed in these calculations, with Δ G ‡ representing the Gibbs free energy barrier difference computed using transition state theory at the reaction temperature and pressure. Using the flash model of Aspen, we calculated the concentrations of CO and H2 in the liquid phase under different reaction conditions. We performed MKM simulations of allyl acetate hydroformylation catalyzed bytwo catalysts using COPASI [66]. (3) k T = σ κ k b T h e x p ( - Δ G ‡ RT ) 2.2 Experimental methods All hydroformylation experiments were carried out in a 50 mL stainless steel autoclave equipped with magnetic stirring. The reagents used were all commercially available. In a typical experiment, Rh(CO)2(acac), toluene, allyl acetate, phosphine ligand, and n-dodecane were added to the autoclave. The system was purged with N2 and syngas for 10 min each to eliminate air. Then, under atmospheric syngas pressure, the mixture was stirred and quickly heated to the reaction temperature. After reaching the desired temperature, the pressure was raised to the reaction pressure and maintained for 2 h with a continuous supply of syngas to ensure the reaction proceeded at the specified pressure. Upon completion, the autoclave was quickly cooled to room temperature and then slowly depressurized to avoid product evaporation. The gaseous product only contained a trace amount of propylene, with no reactants or other products. The liquid product was analyzed using GC–MS (Agilent 6890 with HP-5 capillary column, 30 m × 0.53 mm × 0.25 μ m ), and conversion rates and yields were determined using dodecane as the internal standard. The reactions involved in the process are shown in Scheme 1 , including the hydroformylation (Eq. (1)), hydrogenation (Eq. (2)), and hydrogenolysis of allyl acetate (Eq. (3)), and the hydroformylation of propylene (Eq. (4)). Analysis was conducted solely on liquid-phase products. Given that the formation of acetic acid is accompanied by other hydrogenolysis products, it was not included in the selectivity calculations. The conversion rate of allyl acetate ( X AA ), product selectivity ( S product ), and linear-to-branched ratio ( l / b ) were calculated as follows: (4) X AA = n AAin - n AAout n AAin × 100 % (5) S product = n product n AAin - n AAout × 100 % (6) l / b = n l n b where, n AAin and n AAout are the moles of allyl acetate initially fed into the reaction and remaining in the liquid-phase product after reaction, respectively. n product represents the moles of each product in the liquid phase, while n l and n b specifically denote the moles of 4-acetoxybutyraldehyde and 2-methyl-3-acetoxypropionaldehyde. 3 Results and discussion This study employs the Wilson dissociative mechanism to describe the fundamental reaction steps in the RhH(CO)2P2 catalyzed hydroformylation of allyl acetate, producing linear and branched aldehydes and by-product propyl acetate. The left and right black-line cycles represent pathways for linear and branched aldehyde formation, respectively, while the green line indicates propyl acetate formation. The main catalytic cycle involves four crucial steps: allyl acetate insertion, CO insertion, H2 oxidative addition, and aldehyde reduction-elimination, as shown in Scheme 2 (taking RhH(CO)2(Xantphos) as an example). Possible structures for each step were assessed to identify the most stable conformations. Fig. 1 illustrates the energy profiles for the hydroformylation of allyl acetate to produce aldehydes using RhH(CO)2(Xantphos) and RhH(CO)2(PPh3)2 as catalysts. Additionally, Fig. S2 presents the energy diagram for RhH(CO)4-catalyzed reaction in the absence of ligand modification. The following discussion is mainly based on RhH(CO)2(Xantphos), combined with the experimental results (Table 1 ) to analyze the key steps in the whole process. 3.1 Reaction mechanism of target aldehyde 3.1.1 CO dissociation and olefin coordination The stable 18-electron trigonal bipyramidal structure (RhH(CO)2P2) serves as a common pre-catalyst model in olefin hydroformylation. Theoretical calculations indicate that H atom prefer axial position in the complex [68], and phosphine ligands can coordinate at equatorial (e) or apical (a) positions, resulting in two major configurations: ee and ea. In the hydroformylation process, it is commonly considered that the binding and dissociation of the tetracoordinate catalyst structure with CO or olefin occur in a quick dynamic equilibrium [67,68], with olefin insertion being generally irreversible [69]. Thus, the entire process from CO dissociation to olefin coordination has been considered to identify the most probable starting point for subsequent reactions. Fig. 2 illustrates the energy profiles of ee and ea structures for CO dissociation on RhH(CO)2(Xantphos) and RhH(CO)2(PPh3)2. The ea structure of RhH(CO)2(Xantphos) is 0.46 kcal/mol more stable than the ee structure. It also has a lower CO dissociation barrier of 9.69 kcal/mol, making it more reactive. Conversely, for RhH(CO)2(PPh3)2, despite the greater stability of the ea structure, the ee structure exhibits a lower CO dissociation barrier by 1 kcal/mol. To investigate the stable olefin coordination mode, a series of potential five-coordinate configurations of RhH(CO)(AA)P (AA = allyl acetate, P = Xantphos, (PPh3)2) was constructed. For RhH(CO)(AA)(Xantphos), four different conformations of equatorially coordinated allyl acetate were found in the ee structure, while three different olefin coordination modes were observed at the apical position in the ea structure, depending on whether the acetoxy group was near the H or CO side and the functional group orientation (Fig. 3 ). The energy of the four Xantphos-ee conformations was much higher than that of Xantphos-ea. Regardless of whether the functional group was close to CO or H, the most stable conformation was that with the acetoxy group away from the catalyst, indicating repulsion between the two. The weak interactions within the Xantphos-ea1 and Xantphos-ea2 were analyzed using IRI (Fig. 4 ). Notably, when the acetoxy group is in proximity to the carbonyl group of the catalyst (as in Xantphos-ea1), van der Waals forces are significantly present, whereas they are almost negligible in Xantphos-ea2. This distinction is the source of the observed differences in structural energies. In the Xantphos-ea structure, the carbonyl group repelled the acetoxy group of allyl acetate, causing it to twist away on the equatorial plane and forming a stable quadrilateral with two C atoms of the olefin and one phosphine ligand. Among these, the conformation Xantphos-ea2, with the acetoxy group near the CO side and twisted away, was the most stable. Similar conclusions were drawn from the conformational analysis of RhH(CO)(AA)(PPh3)2 (detailed in Fig. S3). The most stable conformation identified was PPh3-ee2, characterized by the acetoxy group being close to the CO side and oriented away from the catalyst. In summary, considering both CO dissociation and olefin coordination, Rh catalysts modified with Xantphos prefer to bind allyl acetate in the ea2 conformation (referred to subsequently as X-ea), whereas Rh-PPh3 catalysts exhibit greater stability in the ee2 conformation (referred to subsequently as P-ee). Subsequent discussions will be based on these conformations. Additionally, we have conducted comprehensive reaction network calculations for the Xantphos-ee4 and PPh3-ea2 catalyst conformations (see Figs. S4–S5) to comprehensively consider the impact of less stable structures on reaction pathways in the kinetics analysis. 3.1.2 Olefin insertion The transition state of H atom transfer from Rh to the α-C or β-C of allyl acetate is the crucial step in the catalytic cycle, as it determines the position of the aldehyde group and the subsequent formation of linear and branched aldehydes through distinct pathways. Fig. 5 illustrates the insertion process of allyl acetate on X-ea, with green highlighting the breaking bonds and involved atoms in the transition state. When H atom transfers to α-C, the substrate rotates counterclockwise, the carbonyl group twists from the equatorial to the apical position, and the bite angle changes from 100.1° to 115.3°, forming the tetrahedral X-ea-4l structure. In contrast, when H atom transfers to β-C, leading to branched aldehyde formation, the substrate rotates clockwise slightly, the bite angle changes from 100.1° to 99.1°, and minimal movement of the carbonyl group (as confirmed by the IRI analysis of X-ea-TS3l in Fig. 7), resulting in the quadrilateral X-ea-4b structure. In contrast, for the olefin insertion reaction catalyzed by P-ee (Fig. S6), the allyl acetate intermediate encounters greater steric hindrance from the ligand when rotating counterclockwise around the Rh-C(β) axis compared to rotating clockwise around the Rh-C(α) axis, leading to a higher energy barrier for the P-ee-TS3l. The final complexes, P-ee-4l and P-ee-4b, both adopt quadrilateral configurations. To further investigate the steric effects of different ligands and configurations on TS3, stereograms of X-ea-3* and P-ee-3* were created (Fig. 6 ), displaying the relative positions of the olefin and Rh, as well as the free volume fractions in each quadrant. Fig. 6 presents the structure viewed along the z-axis from the olefin side, where R denotes CH2COOCH3. Its projection appears northeastward in four quadrants, in agreement with the actual model, thus serving as the reference for subsequent analysis. The contour lines in the visualization delineate the ligand-embedded space within the Rh coordination sphere along the z-axis orientation, with positive isovalues (shown in red) specifically mapping the top hemisphere where the ligand is situated. For X-ea-3*, the olefin rotates from the northeast to the southeast (%Vf = 43.9 %) to form the linear aldehyde intermediate and from the northeast to the northwest (%Vf = 31.9 %) to form the branched aldehyde intermediate. The linear pathway experiences less steric hindrance than the branched pathway, resulting in a lower reaction barrier. Conversely, for P-ee-3*, the olefin rotates from the northeast to the northwest (%Vf = 41.6 %) to form the linear aldehyde intermediate and from the northeast to the northwest (%Vf = 44.8 %) to form the branched aldehyde intermediate. Unlike X-ea-3*, the linear pathway in P-ee-3* encounters greater steric hindrance, leading to a higher reaction barrier than the branched pathway. In addition, the charge transfer during the reaction was analyzed (Table 2 ). It was found that in X-ea-3*, Rh carries a charge of −1.275|e|, and the β-C serves as a negative charge center, readily attracting the transferred positively charged H, consistent with Markovnikov's rule. However, the O atom in the Xantphos structure not only enhances structural flexibility but also modulates the charge on Rh. As a result, in X-ea-TS3l, the distance between Rh and O is shortened (from 3.52 Å to 3.44 Å), which reduces the charge density on Rh and promotes the combination of Rh with β-C. More research has been conducted on the hydroformylation of vinyl acetate than that of allyl acetate. In vinyl acetate hydroformylation with Xantphos as the ligand, branched aldehyde is the main product. This is because the acetoxy group induces double-bond polarization, making the α-C negatively charged and more likely to bond with the positively charged Rh. During olefin insertion, the α-C and acetoxy group form a chelate with Rh, favoring branched aldehyde formation [70]. For allyl acetate, charge analysis shows the charge on β-C atom is −0.379|e| and α-C is −0.208|e|, indicating Rh is more likely to connect with β-C, which acts as the negative charge center. To investigate the influence of the acetoxy group, we calculated the olefin insertion step for the Xantphos-ea1 (referred to subsequently as X-ea1) with the acetoxy group near the carbonyl and oriented upward. Unlike in vinyl acetate hydroformylation, no chelation structure between the acetoxy group and Rh was observed. TS energy comparisons revealed that altering the position of acetoxy group has opposite effects on the H atom transfer barrier (Table 3 ). The movement of acetoxy group decreases the distance to carbonyl in the production of 4b*, while in the 4l* formation, it increases (Fig. S7). Combining with the IRI study of TS3b (Fig. 7 ), it shows weak interactions between the carbonyl and acetoxy group in X-ea1-TS3b, resulting in a higher reaction barrier than in X-ea-TS3b by 1.12 kcal/mol. This comparison further confirms the repulsion between the carbonyl and acetoxy group in allyl acetate. In contrast, during the formation of 4l*, the acetoxy group in X-ea1-TS3l mainly interacts with the ligand's phenyl ring via van der Waals forces, lowering the barrier compared to X-ea-TS3l by 0.10 kcal/mol. Overall, unlike vinyl acetate, allyl acetate is more prone to forming linear aldehydes. The olefin insertion process is exothermic and can be considered irreversible. When catalyzed by RhH(CO)2(Xantphos), the reaction barrier for forming the linear intermediate is 5.49 kcal/mol lower than that for the branched intermediate, favoring the formation of 4-acetoxybutyraldehyde. Conversely, with RhH(CO)2(PPh3)2 as the catalyst, the barrier for producing the linear intermediate is 4.15 kcal/mol higher than that for the branched intermediate, resulting in a l/b ratio of less than 1. In the absence of the ligand (Fig. S2), the barrier difference between forming linear and branched aldehyde intermediates is minimal, with the linear intermediate being only 0.15 kcal/mol lower, leading to a l/b ratio close to 1. Therefore, similar to most olefin hydroformylations [20], this step is also the selectivity-determining step in the hydroformylation of allyl acetate. 3.1.3 CO coordination and insertion After olefin insertion forms a four-coordinate structure, the subsequent steps involve CO coordination and insertion (Fig. 8 ). Calculations show that in the linear path, CO coordinates to the equatorial site of the tetrahedral (X-ea-4l) complex, while in the branched path, it approaches the apical position of the quadrilateral (X-ea-4b) complex. Both pathways ultimately form a trigonal bipyramidal structure with carbonyl and allyl acetate intermediate at the axial position. During CO insertion, the Rh-C bond cleaves, and the propenyl group bends toward the adjacent carbonyl to form a new bond, creating a distorted quadrilateral. In the P-ee catalytic system, CO coordination results in P-ee-5l and P-ee-5b structures, where the olefin intermediate and phosphine ligand are at the axial position. CO insertion then forms a quadrilateral configuration (details in Fig. S8). 3.1.4 H2 oxidation addition and aldehyde reduction elimination The coordination of H2 to the Rh active center is the highest-barrier step in the entire reaction and is strongly endothermic, which is consistent in both Rh-catalyzed systems with PPh3 ligand and without ligand, as shown in the Table 4 . Thus, H2 oxidation addition is regarded as the rate controlling step of the entire reaction, and primarily influenced by the steric hindrance and charge density of Rh. The charge densities of Rh in the three catalytic systems are relatively similar. The Xantphos-modified catalyst has a lower electron density, which could theoretically make the H2 oxidation addition reaction relatively easier. However, no corresponding trend is observed in the reaction barriers, suggesting that the charge density of Rh is not the primary influencing factor. The spatial distribution of steric hindrance before H2 coordination was calculated for the three catalysts, with the positions of H2 coordination indicated in the Fig. 9 . For Rh without a ligand, the free volume percentages in the linear and branched aldehyde formation pathways are relatively high (57.5 % and 50.5 %, respectively), with low steric hindrance in the quadrants for H2 coordination. The electron densities of Rh are similar, resulting in similar barriers for H2 oxidation addition in both pathways. For ligand-modified catalysts, the steric hindrance is significantly increased, and the free volume is reduced to less than half. The overall free volumes of X-ea-6l* and X-ea-6b* are comparable. Specifically, in X-ea-6l*, H2 coordinates with Rh from the northeast quadrant with a larger free space (39.4 %), while in X-ea-6b*, H2 approaches Rh from the southeast direction (33.4 %), encountering less steric hindrance in X-ea-6l*. The impact of steric hindrance is very evident for P-ee-6l* and P-ee-6b*. In P-ee-6b*, H2 coordinates with Rh from the west, with relatively large free volumes in the southwest (36.4 %) and northwest (28.1 %) quadrants. However, in P-ee-6l*, although there is a free space of 34.6 % for H2 insertion from the northeast direction, the available coordination angle is narrow, leading to a high reaction barrier of 34.17 kcal/mol. Overall, the extent of steric hindrance significantly influences the feasibility of the H2 oxidation addition reaction in the hydroformylation of allyl acetate. To reduce the reaction barrier and increase the reaction rate, catalysts must provide sufficient free space volume and a wider contact angle with the Rh active site. Upon H2 coordinates to the catalyst, forming the octahedral X-ea-7b and X-ea-7l complexes where H atoms are positioned opposite to the olefin and phosphine atom. During aldehyde reduction elimination, H atom from active Rh center transfers to the olefin intermediate, yielding 4-acetoxybutyraldehyde or 2-methyl-3-acetoxypropionaldehyde. After aldehyde desorption, the catalyst reverts to RhHCO(Xantphos) tetracoordinate state, ready for the next catalytic cycle. 3.2 Reaction mechanism of hydrogenation and hydrogenolysis In the process of allyl acetate hydroformylation, by-products include propyl acetate, n-butyraldehyde, isobutyraldehyde, propylene and acetic acid. Propyl acetate, formed via hydrogenation, arises from the formation of tetrahedral structures (X-ea-4b and X-ea-4l) after olefin insertion, where H2 and CO compete for coordination. Therefore, a hydrogenation reaction may occur to produce propyl acetate, and the reaction energy barriers are shown in Fig. 10 (a). Table 5 lists the computed reaction energy barriers for H2 coordination (ER7) and CO coordination (ER4) on various catalysts. The former is all higher, so that the reaction is more likely to proceed along the main reaction pathway, aligning with our experimental observations (Table 1). For the Xantphos-modified catalyst, propyl acetate formation is below 4 % at a syngas ratio of 1, increasing the temperature (Entry5) or pressure (Entry 4) from leads to higher hydrogenation product formation. Higher H2 concentration (CO/H2 = 1/2) boosts propyl acetate yield to 13.28 % by overcoming high barriers (Entry 9–12). Other by-products are thought to be hydrogenolysis products formed at high temperature, and we have conducted experiments to investigate their reactive sites and formation pathways. In the absence of catalyst, only trace amounts of allyl acetate undergo hydrogenation. Without ligand modification, Rh-catalyzed reactions produce 32.29 % hydrogenolysis products (Entry 2), which increase dramatically to 58.19 % (Entry 3) with higher H2 concentration. In contrast, introducing ligands primarily promotes the hydroformylation of allyl acetate, occurring predominantly on ligand modified Rh catalysts. Increasing ligand concentration reduces hydrogenolysis products (Entry 7&8) and enhances chemical selectivity to over 92 %. Besides experimental results, we found that 4-acetoxybutyraldehyde and 2-methyl-3-acetoxypropionaldehyde rapidly desorb after formation and do not adsorb onto the Rh-based active center. Thus, we speculate that allyl acetate is the main hydrogenolysis reactant, with active site being Rh not coordinated by phosphine ligands, a process we have theoretically calculated. Fig. 10(b) depicts the dissociation of allyl acetate on active Rh site to form propylene and acetic acid, where H atom may migrate to the O atom of the acetoxy group instead of α-C or β-C. This step requires overcoming a high reaction barrier of 40.62 kcal/mol, thus being more likely to occur at high temperature. Subsequently, propylene undergoes hydroformylation, yielding n-butyraldehyde and isobutyraldehyde as the final by-products. 3.3 MKM simulation In the preceding theoretical calculations, we constructed a detailed reaction network for the hydroformylation of allyl acetate and calculated the energy barriers for elementary reactions of main products, followed by qualitative analysis. Based on these results, we explored the impact of reaction conditions through MKM simulation and compared them with experimental findings (Tables S4–S9). First, we discussed the impact of metastable conformations on reaction product distribution. By considering the energy barrier difference for ee and ea isomer interconversion of RhH(CO)2(Xantphos) as the bridge, we connected the complete reaction networks under both conformations. Tracing the sources of product formation further elucidated the impact of catalyst conformation. We investigated the species concentrations and product distribution under the condition of CO/H2 = 1, 353 K, 40 bar, and AA/Rh = 400 (mol). Given that this is a batch reaction, the overall process can be divided into two stages: from the reaction start to the complete adsorption of allyl acetate (stage 1) and the complete formation of reaction products (stage 2) (see Figs. S9–S10). In the linear pathway, the trends of other intermediates over time in the system are consistent with X-ea-4l (or X-ee-4l) formed after olefin insertion, and similarly in the branched pathway, they are consistent with X-ea-4b (or X-ee-4b). The highest concentrations in the linear and branched pathways are X-ea-6l and X-ea-6b (X-ee-6l and X-ee-6b), respectively, which are the intermediates before hydrogen oxidation addition, consistent with the high reaction barriers calculated by DFT. Fig. 11 presents the product distributions simulated with only the X-ea structure and with both X-ea and X-ee structures. The simulated selectivities for linear aldehyde are 93.61 % and 91.88 %, respectively, while those for branched aldehyde are 6.38 % and 8.11 %. Compared to the products formed from the X-ea structure, those from the X-ee are 1 to 2 orders of magnitude lower, primarily influencing the dynamic equilibrium of various intermediate species within the system. Under the given reaction conditions, the MKM simulation of the RhH(CO)2(Xantphos)-ea catalyzed process yields a l/b aldehyde ratio of 14.65, which closely corresponds with the experimental value of 12.86 obtained under identical conditions. Similarly, we simulated the product distribution of allyl acetate hydroformylation catalyzed by different configurations of Rh-PPh3 (Fig. 11(b)). The simulated selectivity for linear aldehyde was 19.62 %, and for branched aldehyde was 80.33 % on P-ee. On P-ee and P-ea, the simulated selectivities were 18.90 % and 81.06 % respectively, with the products mainly originating from the P-ee. In summary, the simulation results demonstrate that the structure with the most stable olefin coordination in the hydroformylation of allyl acetate dominates the system, and the product distribution derived from it can be approximated as the product distribution for the hydroformylation of allyl acetate catalyzed by this catalyst. For the reaction conditions at 353 K and 40 bar, the simulated theoretical isomer ratio of Rh-PPh3 is lower than that of the experiment (0.24 vs 0.58), while the simulated isomer ratio of Rh-Xantphos is higher than that of the experiment (14.65 vs 12.86). We analyzed this difference and attributed it to two aspects. From a kinetic perspective, comparative analysis of the H2 oxidative addition process reveals that Rh-Xantphos displays a 7.67 kcal/mol lower energy barrier for the linear pathway versus the branched pathway, whereas Rh-PPh3 shows the opposite trend with a 17.61 kcal/mol higher barrier for the linear pathway. This indicates that for both Xantphos and PPh3, the lower energy barrier corresponds to the favored aldehyde formation pathway. Thus, it is highly plausible that olefin insertion is the selectivity-determining step, while the differences in energy barriers for the H2 oxidative addition process play a synergistic role. Furthermore, our simulations identified that the product distribution is significantly influenced by H2 and CO concentrations and their ratios (Fig. 12 ), which contributes to the observed deviations. Additionally, inherent differences between the idealized simulation conditions and actual reaction parameters inevitably affect the quantitative agreement. To explore the impact of reaction conditions on product distribution, MKM simulations were conducted for the X-ea and P-ee catalysts, with different reaction temperature (333–373 K), reaction pressure (10–80 bar), and syngas ratio (CO/H2 = 1/8–8). Fig. 12 illustrates the relationship between pressure and syngas ratio with product selectivity at 353 K (for other temperatures, see Figs. S11–S18). As pressure increases, the selectivity for linear aldehydes significantly rises on X-ea, peaking at 94.93 % at 80 bar. At lower pressures, changes in the syngas ratio have a greater effect on product selectivity. For instance, at 10 bar, the selectivity for linear aldehydes is 19.61 % higher when CO/H2 = 1 compared to CO/H2 = 8. At higher pressures, the effect is less pronounced, with a maximum difference of only 2.61 % at 80 bar. Interestingly, the highest selectivity for 4-acetoxybutyraldehyde is consistently achieved at a CO/H2 ratio of 0.5–2 across different pressures, a trend also observed experimentally. In P-ee, a similar trend is observed, where the selectivity for branched aldehyde, as the dominant species, increases with pressure, reaching a maximum of 85.65 %. Across different pressures, the highest selectivity for 2-methyl-3-acetoxypropionaldehyde is consistently achieved at a syngas ratio of 1. This insight guides us in the hydroformylation of allyl acetate to moderately increase H2 concentration to accelerate the reaction rate while maintaining a high selectivity for the target product by keeping the CO/H2 ratio of 0.5–2. Fig. 13 (a) shows the impact of varying temperature and pressure on the selectivity of 4-acetoxybutyraldehyde in the hydroformylation of allyl acetate catalyzed by X-ea at a CO/H2 ratio of 1. With the increasing pressure, the concentration of CO and H2 in the liquid phase increases, resulting in the enhanced selectivity for 4-acetoxybutyraldehyde. Temperature variations have a notable effect on the Gibbs free energy of the elementary reactions involving CO and H2 coordination, with each 10 K rise adding roughly 0.5 kcal/mol to the energy barrier. This results in varying rates of selectivity increase with pressure at different temperatures. Nevertheless, at high pressures like 80 bar, the selectivity for 4-acetoxybutyraldehyde can surpass 98 %. When P-ee serves as the catalyst, increasing either temperature or pressure enhances the selectivity for 2-methyl-3-acetoxypropionaldehyde (Fig. 13(b)), with a maximum of 91.49 % achieved at 363 K and 80 bar. For the hydrogenation product propyl acetate, the influence of reaction conditions on selectivity are shown in Figs. S19–S22. In the simulated hydroformylation of allyl acetate at 353 K, both the Rh-Xantphos and Rh-PPh3 catalytic systems exhibited increased propyl acetate selectivity with rising H2 concentration under varying pressures. Experimental results from Rh-Xantphos-catalyzed reactions demonstrated that the selectivity of propyl acetate increased by 3.36 % at 333 K (CO/H2 = 0.5 vs. 1) and by 4.12 % at 353 K (Table 1, entry 7 vs. entry 10 and entry 8 vs. entry 11), consistent with the simulation trend. The variation in selectivity for the hydrogenation product with changing pressure or temperature was non-monotonic, as increasing pressure or temperature not only accelerated the hydrogen oxidative addition process but also affected CO concentration, involving competition between primary and side reactions. For Xantphos, simulations indicated minimal propyl acetate formation at 60 bar, whereas for PPh3, this occurred at 80 bar. In summary, Table S11 compares MKM-simulated and experimental selectivities under identical conditions. For hydroformylation products, MKM modeling accurately reproduced the regioselectivity trends observed experimentally for both Rh-Xantphos and Rh-PPh3 catalysts across various temperatures and pressures. However, for the hydrogenated products, the simulation results of the Rh-PPh3 are consistent with the experiments, while the Rh-Xantphos has the same trend but quantitative differences. This may stem from dynamic equilibrium between Xantphos and Rh, leaving unmodified Rh sites available for hydrogenation, leading to increased propyl acetate formation. While the predictive performance of the developed MKM model requires further experimental validation under extreme conditions (>4 MPa, H2/CO > 2:1), it demonstrates exceptional regioselectivity prediction accuracy within industrial operating windows, providing reliable theoretical guidance for both process optimization and catalyst design in hydroformylation. 4 Conclusion This study provides a comprehensive understanding of the hydroformylation mechanism of allyl acetate and the impact factors on its product selectivity through a combination of experimental and theoretical calculations, offering a detailed insight into the key intermediate reaction for the synthesis of 1,4-BDO from propylene. Theoretical calculations were employed to investigate the key elementary reactions of allyl acetate hydroformylation catalyzed by Rh-based catalysts modified with Xantphos, which favors the formation of linear aldehyde, and PPh3, which tends to produce branched aldehyde. The results revealed that the olefin insertion is the selectivity-determining step. The acetoxy group in allyl acetate exhibits repulsive van der Waals interactions with the carbonyl group of the catalyst, leading to a more stable conformation where the groups are positioned away from each other. The Xantphos-modified Rh catalyst provides a more favorable reaction pathway for linear aldehyde formation due to the relative lower steric hindrance than that of branched one and the modulate the charge density of Rh through structural flexibility. In contrast, for the PPh3 system, the alkene insertion step along the isomerization pathway encounters lower steric hindrance during rotation, thus favoring the formation of branched aldehyde. The H2 oxidative addition is the rate-determining step of this reaction, where the steric hindrance of the catalyst structure serves as the primary influencing factor. Providing larger free space volume facilitates lowering the energy barrier for H2 insertion, thereby enhancing the reaction efficiency. Additionally, calculations indicated that the hydrogenolysis of allyl acetate primarily occurs at uncoordinated Rh sites, a process that requires a high energy barrier and is more likely to proceed under high temperature or high H2 concentration conditions. MKM further validated the theoretical results and explored the influence of reaction conditions on product selectivity. The simulations demonstrated that the product distribution derived from the most stable olefin coordination conformation can approximate the product distribution of allyl acetate hydroformylation catalyzed by the respective catalyst. The MKM simulation results were consistent with the experimental trends. Increasing pressure and optimizing the syngas ratio (0.5–2) significantly enhanced the selectivity for aldehydes with lower olefin insertion energy barriers. For Xantphos, the selectivity for linear aldehyde could exceed 98 % under optimal conditions. The findings in this work are expected to guide the development of novel industrial catalysts for 1,4-BDO synthesis from propylene, while also demonstrating the potential of a multi-scale approach combining DFT and MKM for exploring hydroformylation catalytic reaction systems. coredata.dc:description: The direct hydroformylation of allyl acetate followed by hydrogenation represents a novel route for 1,4-butanediol production with significant industrial potential and market prospects. In this study, we employed Density Functional Theory (DFT) and Microkinetic Modeling (MKM) to comparatively investigate two representative Rh-based catalysts with distinct product distributions (RhH(CO)2(Xantphos) and RhH(CO)2(PPh3)2), systematically elucidate the mechanisms for improving the selectivity and regulation principles of this reaction. Theoretical calculations reveal that the regioselectivity is primarily determined by the olefin insertion step. Xantphos ligand reduces the electron density of the Rh center and provides a sterically favorable environment for the linear pathway. Additionally, the acetoxy group in allyl acetate exerts a repulsive interaction with the Rh-carbonyl, directing Rh to preferentially coordinate with the β-C, thereby significantly enhancing the formation of 4-acetoxybutyraldehyde. In contrast, the PPh3-modified Rh catalyst exhibits lower steric hindrance along the branched pathway, thus favoring the formation of branched aldehydes. Experimental investigations demonstrate that hydrogenolysis of allyl acetate predominantly occurs at the uncoordinated Rh sites, and the elevated H2 concentration and higher temperature will promote this side reaction. For Xantphos, MKM simulations indicate that the increased pressure and optimized syngas composition (CO/H2 = 0.5–2) can lead to linear aldehyde selectivity exceeding 98 %. Similarly, in the PPh3 system, high pressure and a near-equimolar syngas ratio favor the formation of branched aldehyde. These findings unveil the intrinsic relationships between ligand design, reaction conditions and selectivity, establishing a structure–activity framework for hydroformylation of acetoxy-functionalized olefins. This work provides critical theoretical guidance for the rational design of efficient catalysts and advances the development of scalable 1,4-BDO production process.
